content: The Act is titled the "National Sea Grant College Program Amendments Act of 2008" and references the National Sea Grant College Program Act. The purpose of the Act includes findings and a stated purpose. The National Sea Grant College Program Amendments Act of 2008 amends Section 202(a) to encourage the development of systems for coastal hazards and understand global environmental processes. It also updates the program to include integrated research, education, and extension activities through the National Oceanic and Atmospheric Administration's sea grant college program. The National Sea Grant College Program Amendments Act of 2008 aims to promote activities for the understanding, development, and conservation of ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources through Federal support of programs by sea grant colleges and institutes. It also updates the program to include integrated research, education, training, and extension services. The National Sea Grant College Program Amendments Act of 2008 promotes activities for ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources through Federal support of programs by sea grant colleges and institutes. Subsections of section 202 are amended to include "management," after "development," each place it appears. SEC. 4 amends Section 203 by updating definitions and repealing Section 307 of the Act. Section 204(b) of the Act is amended to include sea grant programs within a national network, administration of the national sea grant college program, and strategic investments in ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources. Technical correction is made to Section 204(c)(2). The National Sea Grant College Program is undergoing technical corrections and amendments to the functions of the Director, including evaluating and assessing activities and encouraging collaborations among sea grant programs. The National Sea Grant College Program is being amended to ensure collaborations among sea grant colleges and institutes, encourage cooperation with Minority Serving Institutions, and increase the number of students graduating in NOAA science areas. SEC. 6 amends Section 205 to increase grant funding limits. SEC. 7 updates services provided by Sea Grant colleges. SEC. 8 introduces fellowships. SEC. 8 introduces amendments to the National Sea Grant College Program Act regarding fellowships, specifying the frequency of updates and the restriction on the use of funds for administrative costs. The sea grant review panel established under the National Sea Grant College Program Act is now renamed as the National Sea Grant Advisory Board. Members of the previous panel can continue serving on the new board until their term expires. Any references to the old panel are now considered references to the new advisory board. The National Sea Grant Advisory Board is established, replacing the previous sea grant review panel. Section 209 is amended to reflect the change. The National Sea Grant Advisory Board is established to advise on utilizing the sea grant college program for addressing the Nation's priorities. Amendments are made to various sections to reflect the change from the previous sea grant review panel. The National Sea Grant Advisory Board advises on the nation's priorities for ocean, coastal, and Great Lakes resources. It also designates sea grant colleges and institutes and reports to Congress biennially on program progress. The Secretary provides necessary support for the Board's duties. The National Sea Grant Advisory Board's membership, terms, and powers are amended to include coastal management and resource development. The Director can extend a voting member's term by up to 1 year. The Board can establish subcommittees to assist in carrying out its duties. SEC. 10. AUTHORIZATION OF APPROPRIATIONS. Section 212 of the National Sea Grant College Program Act is amended to authorize specific amounts to be appropriated for fiscal years 2009 to 2014 for carrying out the title. This includes increasing amounts from $72,000,000 in 2009 to $91,900,000 in 2014. Additionally, changes are made to focus on the biology, prevention, and control of aquatic species.
